In propositional logic, if we consider the statement "The exam must have been difficult" as proposition P, then the statement "The exam must have been difficult or challenging" can be represented as "P or Q", where Q stands for "The exam must have been challenging". Since P implies Q, and Q is essentially restating P using a synonymous term, the disjunction "P or Q" logically follows from the original statement P.

Therefore, from the statement "The exam must have been difficult", we can infer that "The exam must have been difficult or challenging".
